header.title: CLAVICULA SALOMONIS. A HEBREW MANUSCRIPT
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Hebrew Magic

central_thesis: This work presents a newly discovered Hebrew manuscript of the 'Clavicula Salomonis,' arguing for its authentic Jewish character and significance as an operative magical text, providing a crucial historical link to the grimoire tradition and demonstrating its distinct content compared to later, often Christianized, versions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction and Historical Context of Mysticism
structure_content.summary: The author introduces the 'Clavicula Salomonis' manuscript as a source of information on the world of mystery and its historical fascination. He traces the roots of mystic tendencies to groups like the Essenes and Therapeutae, linking their healing arts to King Solomon. Witchcraft is noted as an abomination in the Old Testament, but the human desire for hidden knowledge persisted. The practice of sorcery, though assailed in the New Testament (Acts VIII), continued due to the pursuit of temporal happiness. References to the Alpha-Beta of Ben Sira and the Talmud (Sanhedrin 67b) are made, the latter calling sorcery 'the denial of the Providence of God,' and 'Sefer Hasidim' offering a strong indictment.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Clavicula Salomonis: Its Origins and Variations
structure_content.summary: The 'Clavicula Salomonis' is presented as the foundational text for sorcerers, attributed to King Solomon due to his legendary wisdom and control over worldly delights. The author notes numerous apocryphal works ascribed to Solomon, including 'מפתח שלמה' (Key of Solomon), appearing in Jewish texts like Gedaliah Ibn Jahya's 'Shalsheleth-hakabale'. The book lists various Latin, French, and Italian editions/translations of the 'Clavicula' and similar works, such as those cataloged by Karl Engel. It highlights the non-Jewish character of many existing MSS., particularly those with illustrations deemed blasphemous by Jewish law, and contrasts them with the newly discovered Hebrew text.

structure_content.chapter_title: Discovery and Description of the Hebrew Manuscript
structure_content.summary: Gollancz announces the fortunate discovery of a Hebrew manuscript of the 'Clavicula Salomonis,' previously thought lost, found in his late father's library. The manuscript, copied around 1700, consists of 72 quarto leaves and 7 additional leaves (157 pages total), written in a Hebraic-Italian hand with numerous illustrations. The title-page initially bore 'בעטרה שעטרה לו אמו ספר .... שלמה', with a missing word (likely 'מפתח') intentionally cut out, possibly due to fear of repercussions associated with books of magic. The author argues for the MS.'s distinct Jewish character, noting its invocations, pantheistic spirit, use of 'אל עזרתי', and absence of the Christian concept of Lucifer as a rebel. He suggests an Eastern origin for the MS. and discusses potential connections to Sabbatai Zevi's movement through specific textual details.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Operative System: Prayers, Conjurations, and Experiments
structure_content.summary: The manuscript's core content begins with an 'Introduction to the Book' and a series of prayers (תפלות), many of which contain Cabbalistic names. It then details practical operations, referred to as 'מעלות' (operations) and 'ניסיונות' (experiments). These include instructions for conjuring three human associates or even a dog, requiring preparatory rituals such as washing, incensing, and specific oaths. The system also outlines precise timings (e.g., planetary days), the use of specific vessels and instruments (e.g., magical knife, incense-burner, writing materials), and various types of seals and amulets. The manuscript describes experiments for diverse purposes, from seeing spirits in a mirror and escaping prison to obtaining answers from spirits and harming enemies. A significant section is devoted to the 'Experiment of Simon Magus,' providing detailed instructions for summoning spirits like Lucifer and Beelzebub to answer three questions within a magical circle. The text also includes a long alphabetical prayer listing divine attributes and names.

structure_content.chapter_title: Advanced Magical Techniques and Spirit Catalogues
structure_content.summary: The manuscript delves into more complex magical techniques, including the creation of images for specific hours of the day and night (some attributed to Balinus), and intricate conjurations linked to the 'twelve families that came from Heaven to Earth' (a section noted for its syncretic references to the Koran and Mohammed). It provides details for the 'Operation of the Seal of Bilith,' requiring practitioner purity and specific conjurations to invoke spirits like Bilith, Asmodai, and Shugrun. Catalogues of angels and spirits are presented, often associated with planets, zodiacal signs, and celestial hierarchies, such as Metatron, Adribon, Michael, Gabriel, and Raphael. Instructions for 'walking in the air/cloud' and methods for influencing or controlling spirits are also outlined, emphasizing the power of divine names and Cabbalistic formulae.

key_concepts.definition: A foundational grimoire in Western Esotericism, traditionally attributed to King Solomon, detailing methods for commanding spirits and performing magical operations. This manuscript is presented as a newly discovered Hebrew version.
The specific version of the 'Clavicula Salomonis' described by Gollancz, believed to be the original or an early Jewish rendition, contrasting with later Christianized or corrupted editions.
Divine and angelic names derived from Jewish mystical tradition, used extensively in the manuscript's prayers and conjurations to invoke and command spirits.
The act of formally calling upon and compelling spirits or entities through precise words, formulae, and rituals, often relying on divine authority and specific names of power.
Specific magical operations or tests described in the manuscript, designed to achieve various practical outcomes, such as seeing spirits, gaining knowledge, protection, or influencing events.

Magical objects, often inscribed with symbols, names, or figures, used for protection, influence, or as conduits for spiritual power, such as the 'צורת הא-מרל' (holy Amulet) or the 'חותם בילט' (Seal of Bilith).
A system of magical timing and correspondence where operations are performed on specific days or hours associated with particular planets and their corresponding spirits to enhance efficacy.
A figure from early Christian tradition and Gnosticism, presented in the manuscript as a practitioner whose detailed 'experiment' for spirit evocation is described.

A 17th-century Jewish pseudo-Messiah, whose movement's practices (e.g., specific Cabbalistic substitutions) are noted by Gollancz as potentially influencing or being reflected in the manuscript's transmission history.

practical_system.description: The manuscript outlines a practical system for commanding spirits and achieving various magical effects through a structured approach centered on prayers, conjurations, and meticulously detailed experiments ('מעלות' and 'ניסיונות'). It emphasizes the practitioner's moral purity, physical cleanliness, and adherence to specific ceremonial protocols. The system relies heavily on the authority of divine and Cabbalistic names, leveraging them to compel terrestrial, aerial, and planetary spirits. It prescribes preparatory rituals, consecration of tools, and operations within a consecrated space, often a magical circle.
tools: Wax or Clay Images (צלמים) for specific operations
Parchment and other writing materials (for sigils, talismans)
Incense-burner (for incensing persons, tools, and spirits)
Specific 'Characters' and 'Seals' (חותמות) for compelling spirits and creating amulets
Silk or Linen Cloth (for wrapping consecrated items or for specific rituals)
Amulets (קמיעות) for protection and specific magical effects (e.g., 'צורת הא-מרל', ship amulet)
Whistling instrument (כלי השריקה) for summoning spirits
Magical Circle (עיגול) for protection and confinement of spirits
Glass Vessels (for specific conjurations and scrying)
rituals: Purification and ablution rituals for the practitioner and associates.
Recitation of specific 'Prayers' (תפלות) containing numerous Cabbalistic names.
Formal Conjuration of spirits (e.g., Lucifer, Beelzebub, Bilith, Asmodai, and various angels) using divine names and oaths to compel their appearance and service.
Preparation and consecration of magical tools and materials, including salt, fire, and animal blood (e.g., bat blood, dog blood).
Working within a demarcated magical circle (עיגול).

Experiments for specific purposes: seeing spirits in a mirror, obtaining answers from spirits, escaping imprisonment, finding hidden treasures, influencing love, harming enemies, and gaining knowledge.
Strict adherence to planetary timings and specific hours for operations.
Invoking divine and angelic authorities, often listing hierarchies of angels associated with planets and zodiacal signs.
Recruitment and inclusion of human or animal 'associates' (e.g., dogs), requiring specific oaths and consecrations for them.

relevant_quotes.text: The substance of this work might, as far as concerns its practical value, be looked upon as a combination of folly and daring; but from another point of view, namely, that works of this kind were during the past sought after, studied and believed in, the MS. before us assumes a character of high importance.
The chief work which is supposed to have served as the oracle of all sorcerers throughout history is the famous 'Clavicula Salomonis'.
Solomon plays the same rôle in ancient Jewish Magic as Faust does in the Christian; it is, therefore, not to be wondered at that books on magic are attributed to him.
I have lately had the good fortune to become possessed of what appears to be (as far as I am able to judge) a Hebrew Manuscript of the 'Clavicula Salomonis', until this supposed to have been lost.
The general impression conveyed by a perusal of the work itself is that it is perfectly Jewish in tone.
אחנן ומצוה אני לכל המגיע החיבור הזה לידו שלא יהנהו לשום אדם אם לא יהיה צנוע ובעל סוד וחרון במעשיו במלאכה הזאת

This whole passage is highly interesting, containing among others a conjuration of the 'twelve families that came from Heaven to Earth on the day on which was born the son of the Great Satan—your father!'

אשביע אתכם לוּצִיפֶר וכל חבריך באלקים חיים במלאכי מעלה ומטה בכך וכך ובשם פו"ס וכו' עון אשביע אתכם בבֶל זבוך אדוניכם: עור אשביע אהכם בשמן אשר בידו מפתחות גהינם עליכם אשביע אתכם בלוּצְפר, מלככם אשביע אתכם במגדל תהום, אשביע אתכם בתורת ה' שלא יהיה לכם רשות לעמוד באויר ולא החת האויר ולא בארין ולא תחת הארן ולא במים ולא בתחת המים ולא בשמים ולא תחת השמים ולא בשום מקום בעולם אלא שהבאו מיך אל הסקיס הזה אהה לוציפר עם חבריך או שתשלח שלשה מעבדיך שיגידו לי האמת מכל מה שאשאל מהם בשם אגלא, אגלאיי...

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is of paramount importance for scholars and practitioners of Western Esotericism and Grimoire Traditions. It presents compelling evidence for the Jewish origins and character of a core grimoire, the 'Clavicula Salomonis,' challenging previous assumptions about its predominantly Christian or later syncretic development. The detailed description of the manuscript's content, including specific rituals, divine names, and spirit categories, offers a unique window into operative Hebrew magic, its intellectual underpinnings, and its historical evolution. The identification of potential links to the Sabbatai Zevi movement and the syncretic inclusion of figures like Simon Magus and references to the Koran highlight the complex cultural interplay in magical traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic scholars of Western Esotericism, Jewish Studies, History of Magic, and Comparative Religion. Additionally, serious practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in historical grimoires, Qabalah, and the practical mechanics of traditional spirit evocation, will find this analysis invaluable for understanding the roots and methods of their craft.
